I could tolerate when there was at least a decline bench, but now that there are two smith machines that see little use other than old men doing bench with the bar, or girls doing squats with the bar, it's pretty annoying. 

Chuck one of the new smith machines in the trash, then change the layout to acommodate a barbell bench or two (or a flat and a decline but the flat provides more flexibility), and this place is a 5/5!

Seriously, who's idea was it to add a second smith machine...I doubt there was a bunch of customer feedback demanding a second. I never see anyone using either (except for the aforementioned groups, and then only occasionally).
The nicest Club Fitness I've been to, however it can be extremely crowded at peak hours. Not the best place to find a good trainer.

We've been members here for a long time -- 12 years?  -- but I'm looking for a new gym. I used to love coming here, but the changes they've made are not for the better. They moved all the weights upstairs to make more room for the high schoolers on the first floor, and moved all the aerobic machines to a new, crowded room that still has weights at one end. They shortened the track, which now runs through the weight area, and people are almost always standing on it if you're trying to run. They've closed the upper pool deck, where many of us used to use to stretch, for no apparent reason. And during the entire pandemic, they haven't enforced mask use at all, so if you tried to run on the track, you were typically running between a bunch of maskless, heavy-breathing weight lifters. Yuck. The pools are nice, though they still have no recreational swim for my kids and the slide is closed. Sorry to sound like such a downer, but you can probably do better.

This Y location, as with most Y's, is a multifaceted place of fitness and physical education, suitable for families, couples, singles, seniors and the disabled.

Very affordable. Childcare and classes for those who are interested. Art, financial and diabetic classes for those who sign up. Day camp for the kiddos in the summer. 

There are discounts for military and veterans, and possible sponsorships for folks who have trouble paying for the full membership fees each month.

Now, the bad news that may be a downfall for some (I almost let it keep me from going back, but no...won't let it). 

The staff is (mostly) very nice, extremely nice in fact, especially the people at the front desk and the lifeguards. 

But there is one rather creepy busybody that works around the weights who thinks he knows everything to do with diet and exercise, and will throw people out for "improper footwear" or make comments about people's weight, or what they are wearing. He had the nerve to stare at me, looking up the leg of my clothing, wearing a skort and walk over and tell me that "skirts were not allowed." I was wearing a very modest outfit, as I always do, but I guess that only tiny ladies showing their calves and breasts off were okay with him. I invited him to buy me a new wardrobe if he didn't like my footwear nor my outfit (workout clothes are expensive and I wore a long skort that goes past my knees that I usually wear to church). 

He also intrusively inquired as to what I was doing to lose weight and began giving me unsolicited advice. He was so awkward, flirty and leering at women, and generally embarrassing that I felt sorry for him, and for the last he is married to. A good friend of mine who frequents the Y said he is also known to make homophobic comments and make her gay friend feel uncomfortable. I wondered how he lasted this long, positioning himself to look up my skort as I used the gym equipment. I know I'm not the only one that has issues with him. I won't name him because I have to see him almost anytime I go in and either he eventually will lose his job just because of the way he treats people, or he'll get some "sensitivity training" as is the way of the world nowadays. But he won't ever cause me to think bad of the YMCA because sometimes bad apples slip into places. 

Give the Y a try if you like fitness and being social (I don't like being social but hey, whatever floats your boat).

I have a love hate relationship with LA Fitness. I really dislike their style of "sales" and the way they push the team members to sell you on pretty much everything, but I go to the chain for its convenience. This location is so very close to my office so I sometimes come here.

Pros:  
Staff is friendly and not pushy at all! 
Pretty large

Cons: when I went to do push-ups today the floor was filthy and this gym is so new that it shouldn't be.

The layout they have is really not ideal; I wish they would create a bit more room near the cables so people don't have to be on top of each other to workout.

Definitely not my favorite location, but it gets the job done.

Much larger than the new City Fitness on South Street, but also relatively out dated. The cardio room seems smaller than the one on South Street, and the mats provided are a mess. They're really old and overused- they could benefit from an update!
Nice new equipment.  Gets busy at the usual times.  One hammer strength barbell.

Like other reviewers, I also drive 15 min out of my way to go to this location instead of the one in KOP. I won't risk getting a staph infection by going to the nasty LA Fitness in KOP. As a result, this location is massively overcrowded-- especially the pool. There are several elderly people who hog all the pool lanes to just float around for hours on end; the management seriously needs to do something about this so people who want to use the pool to actually swim laps can. Also, the trainers tend to circle you like vultures. I actually took the time to listen to their sales pitch and the training sessions are massively overpriced. On the plus side, they have a decent variety of classes, the facility is newly updated and clean, and the monthly fees are reasonable.

I honestly have no idea what to really rate this gym. It's so crowded every time I go, there are no machines to work out on. So what's the alternative? Working out on your own in the little free space they have. BUT, the problem is that there is no space because other people are already taking up that extra space.

THEN, they have a lot of treadmills and ellipticals. The only problem is that not all of them work. So when it is crowded, and it looks like there are a few machines open; they're not because they're broken. They are also broken a long time. You'll see the same "being worked on" sign on the same machine for about a month before it gets fixed. 

The pool is a nice perk, but you have to look at the hours to make sure you are not going when there is a water aerobics class going on. The water is warm, and the hot tub is a nice feature. 

Some of the same gym reps I see are really nice. They always greet you and tell you to have a good workout. Some of them are definitely sub-par. You'd stand there waiting for them to scan your card while they are talking with friends or another coworker. I could just as easily scan it myself.

The classes are pretty neat, and reasonable. The instructors are pretty motivating. 

The price isn't worth it. $33 for a gym that never seems to have enough gym equipment isn't worth it to me. On top of that, there is a pretty big membership fee. If there wasn't a cancellation fee, I would have cancelled months ago.

It's honestly laughable that I was a member of LA Fitness before joining NIFS. And, that I gave LA a 3 star review. I want to smack myself in the face. 

The National Institute for Fitness & Sport has EVERYTHING you could ever want in a gym, in my opinion. No contracts, you pay month to month. The joining fee is a little hefty, I couldn't sweet talk my way into not paying it, maybe you'll have better luck than me. Parking is included in the garage across the street for those who are not IUPUI students and finding parking or navigating the garage has never been an issue for me.

One of my biggest issues with other gyms is how difficult it is to find a treadmill or other cardio machine during peak times. I haven't had that problem once at NIFS. Additionally, I love that each machine has its own TV with a headphone plug in - my runs fly by as I watch Southern Charm and Kardashians re-runs. (Don't judge.) 

Other great aspects: 
Indoor running track 
Separate weight room (you can avoid the meatheads with ease!)
Lots of mats for stretching
Clean showers and free towels
Sauna, steam room and whirlpool 
Daily locker access with a key you can pin onto your shorts - no more remembering locker combinations! 

They also seem to have a great and professional staff along with member incentives. I've never taken advantage of any of the monthly programs yet, but I definitely want to, because hello, who says no to free stuff?! 

To top it off, there are so. many. classes. You name it - they have it. BodyPump is amazing, as are the yoga and spinning classes. My only complaint - sometimes the times don't work with my schedule, and the weekend classes are definitely limiited. 

Overall, I'd recommend NIFS to anyone who lives or works downtown. There are a few drawbacks - hours on the weekend are a little bit more limited than I'd like and the monthly membership is pricey, but its worth it to know I am a member of such a reputable, clean and great facility.

So I live in DC, but while I was visiting family in South Jersey I knew I wanted to make sure I got my barre fix. Found La Belle Fit and their Studio Barre classes, read the reviews, and booked two classes since they sounded great.

My experience at LBF started out rough. I got there a bit early, checked in, and sat down. The girl working at the front desk seemed confused about my question about the locker room situation and didn't give me any info about the rest of the facility. A few more people came in for my class, checked in, and wandered out. We were all early so I figured they were just wandering around and would be back. Well, with two minutes left until my class, the zumba class going on showed no signs of ending and I turned to the girl at the desk and said "Am I supposed to be somewhere else?" She looked at me like I was stupid and said "um, yea, two doors down." I do some front desk time at the studio where I take barre and the online system that both LBF and my studio use is the same, which means I KNOW that there is a little star that appears when someone is new to the facility.  So then why this girl didn't give me a little tutorial and seemed so put off by me not knowing where I was going is beyond me.

I chalked that up to a minor annoyance and walked down to the studio, figuring as long as the class was good, who cared about the snotty front desk assistant. Well, I was in for another "treat." The class began with a bang when the teacher just jumped in and said "watch me", rather than explaining what we were doing. After a VERY short warm up (not enough time in my opinion and experience), we began the actual class. I could barely heard the teacher over the music, which wasn't even that loud, so I was constantly a beat behind her, which seemed to make her very upset. The ONLY part of the class that I "felt" at all was the thigh work. The "glute" portion of the class was really just more thigh work - with nothing at all designed to work your butt. The abs section was just a joke, I could've been sitting down anywhere, doing anything at all. And then there was literally NO stretching until the end of class. When I work a muscle to the point of fatigue and shaking, aka the whole point of barre, I want to stretch it right away, while it's warm, not at the end of class, when I haven't worked on that body part for 45 minutes.

To top all of that off, I went to go rinse off (though I really didn't need to because I didn't sweat at all due to the nothingness of class), there are no provided towels in the single bathroom. I have NEVER been in a fitness center that prides themselves of being a "fancy" establishment, enough that they offer face wash, lotion, body soap, etc. that doesn't provide a towel for you. In fact, I've never been in a fitness center period that doesn't provide towels for you after you shower. 

I left LBF with a really bad taste in my mouth and actually didn't go to the second class I had booked. All in all, this was a waste of $40 for 2 classes (actually more expensive that had I booked 2 classes at ANY barre studio in DC, where the cost of living is remarkably higher). I don't know what other options there are for barre in the area, but there has to be something better than this place.

Gold's gym continues to charge even after we cancel. First, cancellation is a hassle... They made both of us come to the gym to submit a membership cancellation. We made the trip and put in our cancellation and yet we continue to be charged. When I called them, they said they have not received our cancellation. They argued that I never put in my cancellation. It took me about 15 calls and countless number of hours on the phone to finally talk to a manager and stop being charged. Seems like an experience that many others are having. SUCH A SCAM.

This LA Fitness is trying their best to steal your money. Just watch out your bank statement every month. I signed up my 6 months training session which started from April 5th 2018, the last charge supposed on September 5th 2018. Then on October 5th, they charged me $200 again since I cancelled mine before October 5th. I have to call bank to dispute this charge. Then the LA FITNESS started to call me, call my husband and call my in laws. I called CORPORATE office and asked my money back, the stupid "manager " was like you used 4 classes in October. I said because you guys told me I have 30 days after my training session done to use my rest classes which I did. He said you did not have classes left. Then you used 4 classes. WHAT? I don't know how many classes I still have? I didn't go gym since July and August. I have 8 classes left that I used in October which I still get charged. I just want to say Mt. Laurel LA fitness SUCKS. The operation manager that curly hair lady gave you careless attitude which made you think cancel your membership is the best choice. I cancelled my membership immediately after I talked both this manager and corporate manager. Because they are useless. CHECK your bank account every month. Highlight LAfitness that line. Trust me if you have money problem with them, cancel the membership immediately. Because you never gonna get that money back!!!

Just tried my first Orange Theory class yesterday morning and guess what? I'm a member now. How did that happen? Lol. It happened because I ended up loving the class and my results that much! It's nowhere near my house, so I have to go fifteen minutes out of my way to get there, but it's worth it in my opinion.  

Let me begin by saying that I'm already a moderately active person. I work an office job during the day but I exercise at a regular gym at least 5-6 times a week. I normally do a mixture of weight training and cardio when I go. I've also recently started adding yoga and Pilates once a week to my routine to develop a stronger core. So do I NEED Orange Theory to lose weight? I don't (because I've lost several pounds on my own already), BUT I love their concept of targeting your maximum heart rate zone and believe it will give me the extra push I need to lose these last few pesky pounds. I do have a Fitbit already and use it to monitor my heart rate, but it's a lot more fun when you're in a class setting with a personal trainer and can see your results from the Orange Theory heart monitor on the screen. It made me feel really motivated to stay in the orange zone, which is the recommended zone (based on your stats) to really burn fat.

The class is a mixture of interval training with cardio and circuit training with weights. It's not for everyone because my fiance tried it with me and hated it lol. However, he has never been a fan of instruction while I've done guided classes for years. It passes by quickly! I recommend trying out one class because it's complimentary and they will loan you a heart monitor. I really like that your results are emailed to you at the end of each class. Some people do complain that it's pricey but you truly get what you pay for and health and fitness are definitely something that are worth the splurge! It amazes me how people are willing to spend hundreds of dollars per month on eating out, cable TV, shopping, etc (you get the idea) but cut corners on health/fitness and only be willing to spend a few bucks on a typical gym membership. At the end of the day, you really can't put a price on the sense of accomplishment you get after you finish a grueling workout that challenges you, or the feeling you get when you look in the mirror and are happy with your physique and progress. You only have one body, so why not take care of it?

This place is overhyped and overpriced.

I purchased a Groupon Sparta Cross fit offered to see what all the hype was about. Initially I was excited thinking it would be a good workout that would enable me to stick to a cardio regime. I lift weights 3 days a week and can't stand traditional cardio.   

Their workouts which they change from one day to the next were nothing but a series of pushups, jumping jacks, squats and other basic callisthenic exercises strung together in very high volumes. The workouts are very basic and extremely repetitive. No creativity and totally lame.  The shocker was that they charge $199 a month for this. No thanks. I'd rather be doing a Beach Body program like P90X or Insanity.

For someone new to daily gym workouts, I didn't quite know what to expect. The facility on Swede Road has been a pleasant surprise - as others noted, nothing frou frou, but solid, good equipment with only minimal wait (6-7 p.m. hour can be packed). The only place you can expect to wait is the pool. It's a rare occurrence that I can go in and immediately get a lane - still trying to find the sweet spot timing for that - but people of all fitness shapes, friendly and convenient. Looks like they are starting up the juice bar again, spiffy new signs were being put up today. Good deal overall.

Ok you have to take this place for what it is.  A no frills, no classes, beginner gym for those who are just getting started or are self motivated.  I'm an unabashed fitness junkie and am here usually six days a week.  There are dozens of treadmills, bikes, and elliptical machines as well as a large free weight and machine weight area.  The machines are in good shape and are all Life Fitness, the best maker imho.  There is also a dedicated 30min circuit area as well as an ab area.

Negatives?  Maybe, depending on what you're looking for.  This is not a pickup or exhibition gym, and many of the members are newbies.  Also, if you are into classes...you're outta luck, as there are none.  What you DO get is a well equipped, modern gym with all the stuff you need...for $10 a month.  Can't beat it.

I love this gym and the friendliness of the front desk people! My only complaints are that the computer system goes down a lot. Last week I couldn't tan 3 times because of that. Also why do the paying customers have to clean all equipment? There are usually 3 front desk people that are always either on their phones or staring at the wall. Why doesn't one of them just walk around the gym n spray down the machines after customer use? Seems a better use of their time and your money and would add to customer satisfaction. You also need small trash cans in the tanning bed rooms, you wipe the machines down n then have to chase the paper towels all over when the fans go on! Need to sell better tanning goggles also, yours dig into the eye sockets!

As October ends, so does the deal to visit this club at no additional fee for those of us with "regular" LA Fitness memberships.

I took advantage of this as much as possible because I'm growing more and more tired of the Hyde Park location having no parking for its members anytime there's an event going on in the area on the weekend.

This so-called Signature Club is very nice, but I really do not understand why they charge extra to come here. There is virtually no difference between this location and at least two other clubs that I visit in Orlando which require no additional daily fee or higher priced membership. My guess is that members of this club are simply paying LA Fitness' cost from building this club (Perhaps the land/garage was a higher cost than expected) and they are passing that debt onto its members.

Sure, I like the over 100 cardio machines and the basketball court, but what else justifies paying a 50% higher monthly fee to go here than all the other clubs in Tampa Bay and Orlando? Sorry, choice of a clean hand or bath towel does not.

Oh, speaking of towels, each one is electronically monitored. Seriously, next time you walk out the exit closest to the parking garage, look up and to the right and you'll see a box mounted on the wall with a digital counter. That counter keeps a running tab of how many towels set off the alarm as they attempt to leave the building.

Also, this LA Fitness really needs to stop its members from running around the cardio equipment like it is a track. It is flat out dangerous, because somebody could step off a machine and just go right into these rubes who choose to run around equipment instead of simply going out on the streets near their homes like everyone else.

And next time any of you Signature Club members are upstairs near the basketball court, pop your head in there and look at the big photo on the far right and tell me that doesn't look like Ashton Kutcher growing a 70's porn star mustache.
When I was a member , staff was always very helpful. Super clean and was able to go work out during any time 24/7

Went to one Mastah Tee's Power Dance Workout class and LOVED it! Definitely will be back. Great music, great vibe, broke a good sweat. Trina knows how to pump up the class to get everyone moving. Definitely will be back.

While I have never been a fan of gyms for my simple lack of knowledge I was surprised how much I was able to do with help of Jay on of trainers during our one on one session. He understood my fear and worked to make comfortable enough to enroll in class something before hand I would have never done. I highly recommend this gym for anyone  from beginners to expects you see all types of ppl and they have the ability to modify a work out to make everyone feel included and proud of themself.

I found my home for barre classes.  I'm laying on the floor of my house writing this review, I just had a class & I can't feel my thighs, abs or arms. Barre is probably the hardest work out I do & they don't play around at La Belle Fit.  
         So far I have taken classes with Tanya & Natalie - both  kicked my butt.  Both are sweet and welcoming, they explained everything, were attentive and I was literally melting into a puddle.  They offer Barre & Barre Bootcamp which adds more cardio, tonight I took the Bootcamp & realized I'm not in shape.  
         If you're looking for a workout that uses weights, bands, mats & balls and will have you literally at the barre & on you're toes this is the place.  Comfort & feeling like a part of the studio is important to me & I feel I get that here in addition to a killer workout.
        La Belle Fit offeres a lot of classes; spin, Zumba, yoga, Pilates, suspension training or TRX and of course Barre.  They have packages where you can do some or all of the classes.  I'm going to be staying here for a while, I really, really like it.

My first time and I really like the gym. That says a lot coming from me because I avoid a gym like the plague. Lots of equipment. Plenty of cardiovascular machines. Helpful staff.  Monthly fee is very reasonable.  24 hour access.

This gym is great. They offer a variety of classes - yoga, hip hop cardio, Zumba, just to name a few! The front desk staff - especially Major - always make me gee welcomed when I go in for a workout. The equipment is in great shape and the sauna and locker rooms are always clean. I look forward to when City Fitness opens back up.

Decent spot and good idea overall for parties and tournament hosting.  Seating like similar spots is limited so bring your own chair.  For tournaments that is actually ideal.  Overall clean and organized considering crowd.

We just moved to California from the east coast with our two boys (11 and 14), and we decided to take a surf lesson as a family.  I wasn't sure how it was going to go-- different ages, different learning styles...I spoke with Matt on the phone, and he assured me that we could take a lesson as a family and it would be great.  We had a WONDERFUL time.  Communication with Matt was excellent-- he emailed the day before to have us meet him at the perfect location based on the weather/water.  He and Austin met us at the beach, and after a ten minute safety talk and prep on the beach, we hit the water.  It was a perfect day of surfing, and we all had such a fantastic time.  Most important, my kids had a great first experience and they left the beach asking when they could go surfing again.  I couldn't have asked for a better day, and we will definitely be back for more lessons!

So it has been nearly a year and a half since I started at Innate, and I'm still a huge fan.  I'm in the best shape of my life, and getting faster, stronger, and fitter by the week...  Innate has grown since I first started, developing a fun, active community (from young single professionals to families to grandparents) and the Saturday workouts are social and tough at the same time.  Even after all this time I'm never bored by the WODs, and every time I think I have mastered one skill, the coaches come up with new challenges.  Five stars all the way.

I have been at OrangeTheory for about 5 months now only doing 4 classes a month.  Even with just a weekly workout there supplemented by my normal workouts, I have seen some results in the way my fitness has improved.  I needed something to help jump start my fitness after hurting my ankle last year and getting lazy and OrangeTheory has been exactly what I needed. The coaches and staff are great and while it is a challenging workout, it is still fun and the camaraderie during the classes can't be beat.  It isn't the cheapest gym ever, but you get so much more out of it when you know you need to work hard!

Yes, very clean, modern facilities that offers many programs. 

If you care about good service and feeling like a valued customer, this might not be the place for you. I find the customer service to be grossly lacking at this level of membership. When signing up for programs, scheduling work outs and even going to the new pool turn out to be cumbersome and problematic - these are not good signs. It's hard enough getting to the gym - once you are there, everything else should be super simple!

Regarding this location in specific, it's dirty and they don't clean enough. This is a germ pool just screaming covid and the people there don't seem to care. LOL

Now regarding club fitness in general, scumbag company ran by thieves and absolute garbage human beings. GO TO ANY OTHER GYM.

I've been working out at this gym for a few months now. It is A-Ok. It's close to my home and convenient, price was right for my budget. Plenty of cardio machines to go around. No community feel, very corporate, but it is what it is, a giant fitness chain. The locker room area has always been clean in my experience, there is a sauna. Nothing feels special about this gym. Sometimes I'm greeted at the door, sometimes not. 

I usually work out between 5:30am and 6:30am. There are always plenty of machines. I've gone around 6pm on a weekday, busier, but still plenty of machines. I've also gone on an afternoon on a Sunday and still plenty of machines. I haven't started using their weights, those seem to be busy, but not packed. I can't really attest to how easy and quick it would be to get a full set of weights in. I think that is probably much easier early mornings. 

They offer free classes with your membership, I haven't gone to any, but the spinning and Zumba classes I've walked by seem to have plenty of space for new people to join. I'll update review if I start going. 

I've never been a member of a HUGE gym like this, so I don't have a lot to compare to. If a better option opens up for me at the right price point I wouldn't hesitate to cancel my membership here. Location is important for my work and life schedule, so for now LA Fitness wins. (Prestige Fitness is just down the right, but at a lot higher price point)

They claim to be a "community-focused nonprofit organization...", we were visiting family from out of town, called to buy a day pass so we can use their gym for an hour or so and the lady who answered informed us "if you are not a YMCA member we can't let you in here" that is the "Community-focused nonprofit" attitude of the YMCA????  Don't bother supporting these people that find it difficult to follow their own mission and vision reason for existence.

Love the new St Pete gym. It's closer for us Sarasota folk, tall, clean, varied, friendly, and fun. If you've never been been rock climbing before I highly recommend checking it out. They have safe, easy instruction on how to get started and it's not a macho environment; climbers are pretty chill in general. 

They have a smaller wall similar in size to the Tampa gym, a much taller wall with lead climbing that requires a more advanced check-off, and a large bouldering area with some roof action. 

There are many auto-belays as well as top ropes set up which is great if you are climbing without a partner. 

I do miss the bouldering top out and of course watching the sick climbers spider- man their way across the ceiling, but hey we can still always go back to Tampa for that! 

Easy parking. Clean, relatively affordable. A great workout without realizing how much you're exercising, and a very mind-clearing sport. Thanks VV for a great new gym and for introducing me to the world of climbing.

It's way too crowded, so crowded that even parking in the 6 level garage is becoming an issue. Granted a lot of people probably signed up because of the New Year and classes, but wow. Cardio equipment is still available, but if you plan on lifting weights expect to wait for almost all equipment. On Monday it was so bad that I was not able to lift weights, Tuesday I gave up as well. Today is Wednesday and it is not as crowded, but I think I need a new gym. 

Aside from the crowd issues, there are many positive aspects at this gym: a large weight room, cool vendors, new equipment, and a friendly staff. Their main issues are overcrowding and construction. Also the gym now has a humidity/ mildew issue, hopefully mold does not start to grow.
Somethings are worth the extra dollar and a Gym is definitely one of them. Feel the vibe and listen to your intuition on if it's really for you to prosper.
